docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican leaders of Congress today abruptly called off budget talks that had been set to take place at the White House and said they would not resume them until President Clinton produced another proposal that moved in their direction. The move left Congress and the President stalemated over how to balance the Federal budget yet reluctant to declare the impasse intractable.

headline.main: BUDGET STANDOFF DEEPENS AS G.O.P. CALLS OFF TALKS

docs.snippet: The Republican leaders of Congress today abruptly called off budget talks that had been set to take place at the White House and said they would not resume them until President Clinton produced another proposal that moved in their direction.        ...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a modest sign that New York City's effort to revitalize lower Manhattan is bearing fruit, the New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it would move 700 employees to a building in the shadow of the World Trade Center. In doing so, the company will receive $6.5 million in tax incentives. Most of the 700 employees now work at the company's headquarters at 26th Street and Madison Avenue, but 125 will be moved from New Jersey. The decision is a coup for the city's efforts to retain insurance jobs, since companies like New York Life have long been a major source of white-collar employment.

headline.main: 700 Jobs, Some From Jersey, Moving to Lower Manhattan

docs.lead_paragraph: THE words "Be your own rock" sound as if they might have been an exhortation offered by a hard-headed coach like Vince Lombardi or a positive-thinking preacher like the Rev. Norman Vincent Peale. But the phrase is actually the centerpiece of a campaign that seeks to use the popular notion of empowerment to polish the tatty image of the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Quirky television commercials that begin appearing tomorrow will introduce "Be your own rock" as the Prudential theme -- a sort of financial version of the Nike Inc. mantra to "Just do it." The theme replaces various versions of the familiar Prudential "Piece of the rock" slogan, all of which were derived from the company's longtime icon, the Rock of Gibraltar. Prudential plans to spend $56 million on the commercials as well as on print advertisements that start running next week in a lengthy list of magazines.

headline.main: Prudential's new campaign suggests that the best person to handle your finances  is . . . you.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the passage of a bill by the Assembly today, the Legislature is close to adopting a law providing newborns and their mothers the option to stay in the hospital for at least 48 hours after birth, siding with doctors who have complained that in many cases mothers are being discharged too quickly. The State Senate passed a similar bill last week, and Gov. George E. Pataki has said he supports it.

headline.main: ASSEMBLY PASSES A BILL REGULATING CHILDBIRTH STAYS

docs.lead_paragraph: The stock market weakened yesterday in sluggish holiday trading, as investors remained worried about earnings shortfalls and the absence of a budget agreement in Washington. "There was weakness in the high-tech stocks and that impacted the Dow industrials," said Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president of Tucker Anthony. "Concern spread that earlier earnings estimates may not come to pass."

headline.main: Technology Stocks Drag Market Down, and Dow Falls 17.34

docs.lead_paragraph: Five of the United States' largest African-American church denominations announced today that they were forming a for-profit organization to pool their resources to provide health insurance, home mortgage loans, credit cards, education, food and durable goods to black Americans. The organization, Revelation Corporation of America, hopes to use the combined buying power of church members to receive cash rebates from participating companies. The rebates would be based on a percentage of the purchases made by members. The corporation would either return the rebates to individual churches or put the money aside in a trust fund to finance housing loans. Leaders of the organization said they would describe its operation in more detail later this year.

headline.main: Black Churches Forming a For-Profit Group

docs.lead_paragraph: When Michael Donaldson joined a health maintenance organization in April, he was H.I.V.-positive and healthy. But as his health declined, he said, the Health Insurance Plan of New York came to seem less his ally than his enemy. When he told his H.M.O. doctor in June that he had pneumonia -- with a high fever, nausea and severe shortness of breath -- he was sent home on antibiotics, he said. Two days later, he was in intensive care in an emergency room.

headline.main: Managed Care Has Trouble Treating AIDS, Patients Say

docs.lead_paragraph: A decade ago, when jury awards skyrocketed in medical malpractice cases, causing insurance rates to double and doctors to threaten to leave the state, New York came up with what seemed like a reasonable solution. Hospitals would add a small surcharge to every bill to help pay extraordinarily high malpractice awards. This new insurance fund would limit doctors' costs, keep them in the state and curb the rising cost of medical care.

headline.main: Fee Buildup In Malpractice Stirs Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: In a bid to rein in rising health care costs, Ontario's new Conservative Government wants the authority to control almost every aspect of doctors' working lives -- from where they set up a practice to the finer details of the care they prescribe. Most doctors in the province have reacted with anger, calling the plan an unprecedented intrusion by government into the workings of the medical system. The legislation that is expected to be enacted into law in the provincial Assembly before the end of this month would go so far as to make doctors financially liable for treatments the government may decide later are not medically necessary. It could allow the government to retrieve hundreds of dollars, for instance, if an obstetrician ordered too many ultrasounds, or tens of thousands if a heart surgeon performed a bypass later deemed unnecessary.

headline.main: Will Ontario Wrap Doctors in Red Tape?
